history.content: That's a great plan! I would recommend moving 127 up earlier in the rotation and 126 a bit later if you can; 126 is going to be pretty difficult as a rising (?) sophomore, and although you won't necessarily gain anything directly relevant for 126 from 170 or 188, you'll gain probability and proof-solving maturity. You probably also want to take 61c earlier; if you are doing any practical ML programming then the coding concepts emphasized in 61C (namely the last 1/3 of the course which focuses on efficiency, parallelism, distributed computing) will be very relevant. 170/188/61C -> 126/127 -> 189/168 (168 is only offered in the fall afaik) -> 161/162 is a permutation of your proposed schedule that I think could work better for you.

children.subject: or sorry, it is the same time slot as 170
as an update, the student's answer doesn't make any sense... if they didn't know, 188 is not being offered this fall

history.content: For some background, I'm a declared cs sophomore (done with 61ab70 + 16ab + math53) and planning on doing 4 yr masters on the ML track. My plan is (in order) 126/170, 61c/188/161, 127/189, and 168/162 — however I understand that a lot of machine learning is statistical so I wonder if 70 and 126 are enough probabilistic foundation. If not, which EECS classes can help supplement that, and if not in EECS, what stats/IEOR classes should I take? Also, if there are any order changes in my schedule that you'd find more appropriate to balance / any other classes and advice please let me know! Thank you!
history.subject: Can I build a foundation for ML without taking classes in stats department?
